dailyPosts.tit: Exploring Bootstrap 5 with Angular — Creating Dropdown
dailyPosts.des: Bootstrap 5 is nothing but love and a dream come true for many developers. With its many features and ability to fight alongside any JS framework makes it insanely powerful. This article focuses on getting along with Bootstrap 5 with super heroic Angular.

dailyPosts.des: Debugging mode can greatly increase productivity by helping you step through the code and watch the state of variables and the result of each line execution.

dailyPosts.tit: Structural Directives in Angular - How to Make It Strict (In-Depth)
dailyPosts.des: Structural Directives are one of the most powerful features in Angular and this is the 3rd episode of the video series about Custom Structural Directives. From this tutorial you will learn how to make types in your directives more strict, so you will leave less space for potential errors which otherwise might be caught too late when the user already interacts with your App in production. I hope you will learn a lot of new tricks today. Let me know if you like the video!

Angular Basics: Router Links and Wildcard Routing in Angular
dailyPosts.des: Let's take another look at routing in Angular—this time how you can use the router link to set up wildcards, so nonexistent URLs bring up a 404 page or redirect users to another page.

dailyPosts.tit: How to Share Data Between Pages in Ionic Apps using Angular
dailyPosts.des: In this video I will show you basic patterns to manage and send data in your Ionic app between pages, modals and components.

dailyPosts.tit: What the heck is HttpContext in Angular?
dailyPosts.des: Have you heard about HttpContext in Angular? If not, there is such a thing. HttpContext is used to pass additional metadata to HTTP Interceptors in Angular.

dailyPosts.tit: ConnectTech2021 - Mike Hartington Deep Dive into Angular Builders
Setting Page Titles Natively With The Angular Router
dailyPosts.des: When building applications with Angular, one common thing you should do is have the page title update after each successful navigation. This helps with accessibility and improves the navigation experience. This is something you've had to do manually in the past, but a recent feature added to the Angular Router coming in version 14 handles this natively, while allowing you to customize its behavior. This post shows you how to use the Angular Router's new built-in feature to for setting the page title after each successful navigation.

dailyPosts.tit: Provide and conquer — Injected Angular forms
dailyPosts.des: UX often dictates that complex forms should be broken down to steps, which are spread in multiple pages, and each one is typically validated separately. Sometimes it is also sent to the server for intermediate storage before the final submission. Using Angular, a common approach is to create one form per page, within the container component. The form is validated on submit, before moving to the next step. The form data is either stored in a service, populating the final model, and/or sent to the server. This approach works fine, however it is limited. Navigating between steps might cause inconsistencies as a change in a previous step might have impact on the final model data.

dailyPosts.tit: ConnectTech2021 - Sergio Brito How to Organize an Angular Project
ConnectTech2021 - Patricio Vargas Performant and Accessible Angular Apps as PWAs
Single Component Angular Modules and Component Tests go hand in hand
dailyPosts.des: Writing a good test is not as simple as it sounds, it takes some guidance and practice to get it right. One of the key factors that make a good test stand out is the arrange (or setup) part. For Angular component tests, Single Component Angular Modules (SCAMs) help to make the difference between an OK test and a good test. With SCAMs, you end up with no fragile test setups with half of the code, which results in a happy and productive, team that isn't afraid to move things around.

dailyPosts.tit: Why component store is a great default for state management in Angular
dailyPosts.des: In this video, we walk through how to use @ngrx/component-store to manage local state in an Angular application. We use an example application from a previous video that needs to manage login form state.

dailyPosts.des: In this article we will take simple scenario to learn more about routing, dependency injection, making use of useFactory for providing dependencies during runtime etc. The same concept can be used to build more complex scenarios as well.

dailyPosts.tit: @ViewChild in Angular | Data Binding | Angular 12+
dailyPosts.des: In this lecture, you are going to learn about @ViewChild decorator in angular. The @ViewChild decorator in angular is used to access an HTML element, a component or a directive in the component class.

How to build a JamStack app with Angular Scully and Prisma
dailyPosts.des: By using Angular Scully and Prisma we have a powerful ecosystem where we can leverage full type safety and easily connect to a database that contains data that will be injected into the components by Scully. After the Scully process, we can upload our app to a CDN and have a fully working SEO-friendly Angular app.

dailyPosts.tit: How to build a JamStack app with Angular Scully and Prisma
dailyPosts.des: The App Shell has overtaken the web industry with a whir. And it's no wonder because users are demanding that we deliver faster experiences. No one tolerates slow web apps these days. And the demand only accelerates the app shell architecture boom even more.
